tuv.seg: Supports for postnatal depression
Tacaíochtaí do dhúlagar iarbhreithe
Many women suffer "the baby blues" during the first weeks after childbirth
Fulaingíonn go leor ban ísliú meanmna sa chéad cúpla seachtain tar éis breith linbh
Giving birth can be a highly emotional and physically traumatic experience and the sudden drop in hormone levels following birth can leave you emotionally and physically drained

Eachtra chorraitheach agus fíor fhisiciúil é leanbh a thabhairt ar an saol agus de bharr titim i leibhéal na hormón tar éis na breithe is minic go mothaíonn mná traochta go fisiciúil agus ó thaobh a mothucháin
You may feel weepy, hyper-sensitive, anxious and alone in the world
Is féidir leo a bheith caointeach, hipearmhothaíoch, faoi dá mbeidís fágtha ina n-aonar sa saol
About 80% of women feel like this and will experience "the baby blues" at some point following the birth of their baby
Tuairim is 80% de mhná a mbíonn páistí acu a fhulaingíonn mar seo agus beidh ísliú meanmna orthu ag am éigean tar éis breith a linbh
These feelings will usually pass, with some rest and physical and moral support from your partner, family and friends
Go hiondúil tagann mná chucu féin le beagán scíthe agus le tacaíocht fisiciúil agus spride óna bpáirtithe, óna dteaghlaigh agus ó chairde
However, you may be one of the 10% of women who go on to develop postnatal depression
Áfach d'fhéadfadh sé go bhfuil sí i measc an 10% de mhná a fhulaingíonn ón dúlagar iarbhreithe
Postnatal depression usually begins 2 to 8 weeks following birth, but can sometimes appear up to 6 months or even a year after birth
Tosnaíonn an dúlagar iarbhreithe go hiondúil idir 2 agus 8 seachtain tar éis na breithe, ach anois is arís tagann sé chun solais 6 mhí nó bliain fiú tar éis na breithe
Unfortunately, many women experience this form of depression without even being aware of the symptoms or the fact that postnatal depression is a real illness
Sa drochuair, bíonn an dúlagar seo ar go leor ban i ngan fhios dóibh féin nó gan tuiscint a bheith acu gur fíorghalar atá sa dúlagar iarbhreithe
They experience some of the following feeling:
Tá aon cheann de na mothucháin seo acu:
• Feeling that you can't cope with your baby
• Mothú nach féidir leat déileáil le do leanbh
• Exhausted but unable to sleep
• Traochta ach nach bhfuil ar do chumas codladh a dhéanamh
• Excessive anxiety about your baby
• An iomarca imní faoi do leanbh
If you are experiencing some of these feelings, you may be suffering from postnatal depression and you should ask for help
Má tá aon cheann de na mothucháin seo agat, b'fhéidir go bhfuil tú ag fulaingt ó dhúlagar iarbhreithe agus ba cheart duit cúnamh a iarraidh
Talk to your family doctor (GP) or public health nurse or someone you can trust
Labhair leis an dochtúir teaghlaigh nó le haltra sláinte poiblí nó le duine gur féidir leat muinín a bheith agat aisti/ann
If you don't feel up to making an appointment to see your GP or public health nurse, ask someone to do this for you or arrange for a home visit
Muna bhfuil tú féin in ann coinne a dhéanamh leis an dochtúir nó leis an altra sláinte poiblí iarr ar duine eile é seo a dhéanamh ar do shon nó iarr ar an dochtúir/altra teacht chuig do theach
Healthcare professionals have experience with this type of depression - they will listen to you, and will be able to discuss available options with you
Tá cur amach ag gairmithe cúram sláinte ar an saghas seo dúlagair – éistfidh siad leat, agus beidh siad in ann plé a dhéanamh leat ar na roghanna atá ar fáil
Postnatal depression can happen to any woman and can occur at any time after your baby is born - treatment is very successful, so it is important to recognise the symptoms and seek help

Féadfaidh dúlagar iarbhreithe teacht ar aon bhean agus féadfaidh sé tarlú ag aon tráth i ndiaidh go saolaítear do leanbh – bíonn an chóireáil an-rathúil, mar sin, is tábhachtach na siomptóim a aithint agus cabhair a lorg
If you have had your baby recently, the maternity hospital may be able to help
Má bhí an páiste agat le deireanas b'fhéidir go mbeadh cúnamh ar fáil duit ón ospidéal máthaireachais
Contact the midwife or doctor who cared for you during your pregnancy
Déan teagmháil leis an mbean chabhartha nó leis an dochtúir a thug aire duit agus tú ag súil leis an bpáiste
It is possible you may be referred to the hospital psychiatrist, who will discuss your depression with you and will look at available supports
D'fhéadfadh sé go mbeadh coinne déanta duit le síciatraí an ospidéil, labharfaidh sé/sí leat faoin dúlagar atá ort agus inseoidh sé/sí duit faoin tacaíocht atá ar fáil duit
The hospital social work department will also be able to help
Beidh cúnamh ar fáil duit freisin ón rannóg oibre sóisialta atá ag an ospidéal
Advice for family and friends
Comhairle do theaghlaigh agus do chairde

If your partner, family member or someone you know is suffering from postnatal depression, it is important to recognise the symptoms and remember that this illness is very real but also very treatable

Má tá do pháirtí, duine den teaghlach nó bean ar d'aithne ag fulaingt ón dúlagar iarbhreithe tá sé tábhachtach na comharthaí a bhaineann leis a aithint agus a chuimnhiú gur galar atá ann gur féidir cúnamh a chur ar fáil lena aghaidh
As a friend or family member, you will need to provide lots of support and help - as with all illnesses, recovery may be slow and there will be good and bad days

Mar chara nó ball den teaghlach beidh ort go leor tacaíochta agus cúnaimh a chur ar fáil - i gcás galair ar bith d'fhéadfadh sé go mbeadh sé píosa go mbeadh biseach ar an duine agus beidh laethanta níos fearr ná a chéile
The Health Service Executive (HSE) has produced a free booklet, Postnatal Depression (pdf) which may be of assistance
D'fhoilsigh Feidhmeannacht na Seirbhíse Sláinte leabhrán saor in aisce dar teideal Storm iarbhreithe (pdf). Is féidir a bheith ina cúnamh
Any of the following organisations can offer friendship, advice and support
Tá cairdeas, comhairle agus tacaíocht ar fáil ó na heagrais seo a leanas
